section.title: Gaussian Elimination and Matrices
section.introduction: Then, Gaussian elimination can be reframed in terms of modifying rows of the augmented matrix of a system.

subsection.title: Elementary Row Operations

definition.title: Elementary Row Operation

ul.li: Interchange. Interchange two rows in the matrix.
Scaling. Multiply (or divide) an equation by a non-zero real number.
Replacement. Add to one equation a multiple of another equation.

definition.p: These row operations are denoted symbolically by,

ul.li: R_i \leftrightarrow R_j, interchanging row i and row j.

subsection.p: Performing Gaussian elimination with this matrix form removes the need of repeatedly writing the variables. This process on a matrix is also called row reduction.

ul.li: Two matrices are row equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by a (finite) sequence of row oeprations.
A zero row has only zeros. A non-zero row is a row with at least one non-zero entry.
The leading entry of a non-zero row is the left-most non-zero entry. It is also called the leading coefficient, or pivot.

section.subsection:
Row Echelon Form
After Gaussian elimination is performed on a matrix, the staircase or triangular form of the matrix is called row echelon form.
A matrix is in row echelon form (or simply echelon form, or REF) if,
Any zero rows are the bottom of the matrix.
the leading entry of every non-zero row is always strictly to the right of any leading entry above it.
Matrices in row echelon form have the broad form,
\begin{bmatrix} a \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \\ 0 \amp b \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp c \amp \ast \amp \ast \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp d \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}
where the pivots $a, b, c, d$ are non-zero numbers. Notice that,
Every entry below a pivot is 0.
The leading entries are staggered to the right as we go down.
All zero rows are at the bottom.
The terminology echelon is due to the step-like pattern of the non-zero entries of the matrix. The process of transforming a matrix into row echelon form is called row reduction. In summary,
\begin{pmatrix} \text{doing operations on a} \\ \text{system of equations} \\ \text{to convert it to triangular form} \end{pmatrix} \quad \iff \quad \begin{pmatrix} \text{doing row operations on a} \\ \text{augmented matrix} \\ \text{to convert it to row echelon form} \end{pmatrix}
A pivot position in a matrix A is a location which corresponds to a leading entry in the row echelon form of A. A pivot column is a column of A which contains a pivot position.

subsection.title: Summary of Row Reduction
subsection.p: Consider a matrix A. Broadly, row reduction involves going column by column, reducing the matrix to a simpler matrix at each step.

ol.li:
Use row replacement operations to create zeros in all positions below the pivot. That is, add multiples of the top row to rows below it as to remove all entries below the pivot entry.
\begin{bmatrix} \mid \amp \mid \amp a \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \\ \mid \amp \mid \amp 0 \amp \ast \amp \ast \amp \ast \end{bmatrix}

subsection.p: Finally, to convert the matrix to RREF,

ol.li: Starting with the right-most pivot, use replacement row operations to create zeros above each pivot. If a pivot is not 1, make it 1 using a scaling operation.

subsection.p: Steps 1-3 to convert a matrix to REF is called the forward phase of Gaussian elimination. Step 4 to convert it to the unique RREF is called the backwards phase.

subsection.title: Remark on Gaussian Elimination
subsection.p: Gaussian elimination, despite its simplicity, is one of the most important algorithms in linear algebra. Notice that Gaussian elimination is not really much more than high school algebra, but done in a systematic way.

Gaussian elimination is named after German mathematician Carl Friedrich Gauss (1777-1855), who developed the method in his work and helped develop the formal theory of matrices. However, similar methods of elimination were known as early as around 250-100 BC by the ancient Chinese. German engineer Wilhelm Jordan (1842-1899) helped popularize the method.

subsection.title: Systems with Infinitely Many Solutions
subsection.p: If the REF of the augmented matrix of a system has a zero row, then the system has infinitely many solutions.
subsection.definition: Variables which correspond to pivot columns are called basic variables. The other variables are called free variables.
subsection.p: In general, for the augmented matrix of a system in REF, any non-pivot column corresponds to a free variable (besides the right-most constant column). Free variables can take on any value, and then we can solve for the basic variables in terms of the free variables.

subsection.title: Systems with No Solution
subsection.p: If the REF of the augmented matrix of a system has a row which corresponds to a false statement, then the system has no solution.

section.subsection:
Reduced Row Echelon Form
The row ecehlon form of a matrix is not unique, in that, by doing different sequences of row operations, the final row echelon forms can be different. However, we can continue to apply row operations in order to simplify the matrix further into reduced row ecehlon form.
A matrix is in reduced row echelon form (RREF) if,
The matrix is in REF.
Every pivot is 1.
Every pivot is the only non-zero entry in its column.
In short, RREF goes further than REF by requiring that every pivot is 1 (rather than just any number), and that there are all 0's below and above each pivot. A classic example of a matrix in RREF is a matrix of the form,
\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp a \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp b \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp c \end{bmatrix}
This represents a system of 3 linear equations in 3 unknowns. In particular the system,
\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1x \amp + 0y \amp + 0z \amp = \amp a \\ 0x \amp + 1y \amp + 0z \amp = \amp b \\ 0x \amp + 0y \amp + 1z \amp = \amp c \end{array}
In other words,
\begin{array}{rrr} x \amp = \amp a \\ y \amp = \amp b \\ z \amp = \amp c \end{array}
from which the unique solution can be read right off as (a,b,c).
Basically, RREF builds in the back substitution into the row reduction procedure.
Consider the system,
\begin{array}{rrrrr} 2x \amp + y \amp + z \amp = \amp 1 \\ 4x \amp + y \amp \amp = \amp -2 \\ -2x \amp + 2y \amp + z \amp = \amp 7 \end{array}
which has augmented matrix,
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 4 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ -2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 7 \end{array}\right]
After reducing to REF, one possible form is,
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 1 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp -2 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp -4 \end{array}\right]
We could perform back substitution as before, but we can also instead convert to RREF. Doing so gives,
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \end{array}\right]
from which the unique solution (-1,2,1) can be read right off.
Uniqueness of RREF
Every matix is row equivalent to a unique matrix in RREF.
EXERCISE.
section.p: The process of converting a matrix into RREF is sometimes called Gauss-Jordan elimination, due to Gauss and also Wilhelm Jordan.

theorem.p: A linear system is consistent if and only if the right-most column of its augmented matrix is not a pivot column. In other words, if and only if the REF of the augmented matrix has no row of the form,
If a linear system in consistent, then the solution set is either:

ol.li: A unique solution, if there are no free variables.
Infinitely many solutions, if there are at least one free variable.

subsection.title: Summary of Solving Systems with Gaussian Elimination

ol.li: Determine the augmented matrix of the system \begin{bmatrix} A \mid b \end{bmatrix}.
Convert the matrix into an equivalent matrix in REF, using row reduction. If the system is inconsistent, then we are done.
If the system is consistent, then convert the matrix into RREF.
Write the system of equations corresponding to the matrix in RREF.
Solve for each basic variable in terms of any free variables.
